title: Projection (relational algebra)
summary: In relational algebra, a projection is a unary operation written as Π a 1 , . . . , a n ( R ) {\displaystyle \Pi _{a_{1},...,a_{n}}(R)} , where R {\displaystyle R} is a relation and a 1 , . . . , a n {\displaystyle a_{1},...,a_{n}} are attribute names. Its result is defined as the set obtained when the components of the tuples in R {\displaystyle R} are restricted to the set { a 1 , . . . , a n } {\displaystyle \{a_{1},...,a_{n}\}} – it discards (or excludes) the other attributes.[1]
